_exec_summary.SummaryText:
lden Road Water Treatment Plant has had no chemical accidents within the last 5 years.

6.0  Emergency Response 
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant has prepared a written emergency response/action plan that complies with the RMP Rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Planning Committee LEPC/EMA and local fire department under the coordination rules of the RMP.

7.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant continuously strives to improve the safety of our processes through incident investigation, Process Hazard Analysis, and employee suggestions.  Our engineering and technical personnel stay abreast of technology advancements which may improve the safety of our processes.

/tagout, hot work, confined space entry and line or equipment opening,
 training of maintenance personnel, and
 documentation of maintenance activities.

4.6 Compliance Audit
The Golden Road Water Treatment Plant conducts compliance audits of the Risk Management Program at least every three years. Audits are conducted by a team of hourly and management personnel who are knowledgeable of the RMP Rule and the Chlorination Process. The team evaluates the Golden Road Water Treatment Plant Prevention Program and other aspects of the Golden Road Water Treatment Plant Risk Management Program. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, appropriate enhancements to the Prevention Program are implemented, and maintains records of at least the last two audits conducted. 

4.7 Incident Investigation 
If an event occurs that results in an accident or a near miss, the Golden Road Water Treatment Plants Incident investigation policy would be implemented;  results of this policy include documentation of investigation, resolution of issues identified, implementation of process improvements identified and discussion of results with applicable employees. 


4.8  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
Industry standards are followed at the Golden Road Water Treatment Plant to help ensure safe handling of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia.  The vendor supplies anhydrous ammonia via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved 1 ton cylinders or tanks.  The Chlorination Process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine or anhydrous ammonia receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by the Golden Road Water Treatment Plant. 

5.0 Five Year Accident History

 normal startup,

 The written operating procedures include:

4.4 Training
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant trains workers to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. This training program includes initial training which includes the components below, and is followed by hands on training with an experienced operator until proficiency has been demonstrated. Refresher training is conducted at least every three years and includes the following components:
 a general overview of the Chlorination Process,
 the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and
 a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.
 verification of employee understanding of hazards and safe operating procedures. 

4.5  Mechanical Integrity
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant maintains the mechanical integrity of Chlorination Process equipment to help prevent failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant mechanical integrity program includes:
 an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails,
 a quality assurance program to help ensure that the new and replacement equipment meet the design standards required for service in our process,
 procedures for safe work practices such as lockout

shing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the Chlorination Process are not compromised.

4.2 Process Hazard Review
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant performed and will periodically update process hazard review (PHRs) of the Chlorination Process to help identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process.  Within this program, the Chlorination Process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

To perform the PHRs, City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant primarily uses the What-if/Checklist technique.  The PHRs are conducted using a team of people with experience in engineering and Chlorination Process operation and a leader with experience in process hazard analysis techniques. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and/or mitigation measures, when appropriate.  The team then prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations ranked according to relative risk ratings assigned by the team.  

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the Chlorination Process is no longer in operation.  The results and findings of these updates are documented and retained.  


4.3 Operating Procedures
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant engineers, operators, and management work together to develop and maintain written operating procedures to define how tasks related to the Chlorination Proces

.1 Process Safety Information

The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant maintains a variety of technical documents that help ensure the safe operation of our processes.  These documents address:
 physical properties of hazardous substances handled,
 chemical properties and associated hazards of those substances,
 operating parameters and limitation(s) of the process equipment,
 design basis and configuration of the equipment, and
 specific chemical inventories.

The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant ensures that the process safety information is available to all City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant employees, the 
Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the local fire department.  

Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). 
This information is supplemented by other technical information specific for these chemicals.  Continuous attention is given to revisions and updates on the hazards of anhydrous ammonia and other chemicals used in our process.  Information regarding toxicity, environmental impacts, corrosion concerns, inadvertent mixing hazards, and other safety and health concerns are addressed and communicated to the appropriate parties.

The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design, construction, and operating parameters of process equipment.  This information includes:
 materials of construction,
 design pressures,
 temperature ratings,
 electrical ratings,
 flow limits,
 block flow diagrams,
 consequences of deviation from operating limits,
 safety systems,
 applicable design codes and standards,
 process chemistry, and
 design basis for relief and ventilation systems.

All the above mentioned information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provide a basis for establi

of a full storage tank of anhydrous ammonia.  An alternative release scenario (ARS) for anhydrous ammonia releases is a release from a transfer hose failure.  By evaluating and modeling the potential consequences of these scenarios, we are better able to focus our efforts regarding emergency prevention and response specific to each chemicals hazard.

4.0 Accidental Release Prevention Program
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant performed an offsite consequence analysis to estimate the potential impacts of accidental releases of the anhydrous ammonia from our process. The regulated substance was evaluated for a possible worse-case release scenario and alternative release scenario. It is important to understand that the City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant has invested extensive resources to prevent releases, and the potential for a worse-case release is extremely small. The alternative release scenario represents a more realistic potential for occurrence and is based on historical data from our process or other similar processes. By identifying these potential releases, the City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant has developed an extensive program to prevent such an occurrence. This program is discussed in detail in the Prevention Program section of this plan.

The primary objective of performing the offsite consequence analysis is to determine the distance at which certain effects might occur to the public and/or the environment as a result of an accidental release.  This point is called the endpoint distance.  At distances less than the endpoint distance, the effects would be greater; at distances farther than the endpoint, the effects would be less.

The RMP Rule requires that a prevention program be established for The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant Chlorination process. The following details the prevention program elements at The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant that apply to these processes.

4

City of Tyler
Golden Road Water Treatment Plant
Risk Management Program  
Executive Summary

1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant is committed to the safety of our workers, the public, and the environment. The resources invested in the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances demonstrate this commitment. The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant implements reasonable controls, such as training of personnel and the safe design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to make every effort to prevent the release of hazardous substances but in the event of a release, our trained personnel will coordinate with local emergency response agencies and first responders to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injuries to the public or the environment.

2.0 Description of The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant and Regulated Substances

The City of Tyler Golden Road Water Treatment Plant handles two substances regulated by the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) in quantities above the Threshold Quantity. These substances are:

Regulated Substances: 	Chlorine
			Anhydrous Ammonia
	
Process Description: Part of the Chlorination process at the Golden Road Water Treatment Plant includes the use of Chlorine and anhydrous ammonia to form chloramines. When compared to chlorine disinfection, chloramination can provide better protection against certain bacterial regrowth due to greater residual stability than free chlorine alone. 

3.0  Hazard Assessment - Toxic Substances
In order to aid the RMP Team in accident prevention planning, we have conducted a conservative analysis of accidental release scenarios including modeling, population surveys and environmental assessment of potential consequences. 

The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with Regulated Toxic Substances is a failure
